text.p: --BIRTHDAYS--
Italian romantic opera composer GIUSEPPE VERDI was born in 1813. He wrote "Rigoletto" and "Aida".
Actress HELEN HAYES was born in 1900.

Playwright HAROLD PINTER was born in London in 1930. He was originally an actor but turned to writing for the theatre. He specialised in tragicomedy exploring the breakdown in communication. His plays included "The Birthday Party" (1958),
"The Caretaker" (1960), "The Homecoming" (1965) and "Betrayal" (1978).
British bass player ALAN CARTWRIGHT with the band 'Procol Harum' was born in 1945.

American singer/songwriter DAVID LEE ROTH was born in 1955. He was a member of 'Red Ball Jets' which joined with the 'Van Halen Brothers' to form "Mammoth'. After becoming the loudest group west of Mississippi they called themselves 'Van Halen'. In 1978 their first hit was a million seller - "Jump". LEE ROTH's
first solo hit was with "California Girls" in 1985. He left the band and continued his solo career. Hits have included "Just A Gigolo" (1985) and "Just Like Paradise" (1988).
Country singer TANYA TUCKER, who had her first hit when she was 13, was born in 1958. She has had ten number one hits. Her biggest crossover hit was "Lizzy And The Rain Man" (1975).
British bass player with 'Spandau Ballet' MARTIN KEMP was born in 1961.
--EVENTS--
1874 : The ruling chiefs of Fiji ceded the South Pacific
islands to Britain.
1881 : CHARLES DARWIN published what he considered his

major work. However "The Formation of Vegetable Mould through the Action of Worms with Notes on their Habits" did not attract the same attention or ultimately the same world-wide acclaim as his "Evolution of the Species".
1903 : British suffragette EMMELINE PANKHURST formed the
Women's Social and Political Union to fight for female emancipation.
1911 : Chinese nationalist leader SUN YAT SEN proclaimed
a Republic at Wuchang and began the revolution which overthrew the Manchu dynasty.
1913 : The final obstacle in the creation of the Panama
Canal was overcome when US President WOODROW WILSON pushed a button in the Oval office to detonate the explosives, almost six and a half thousand kilometres away. The final stretch of the
canal was then cleared. American military engineers had spent nine years on the 82 kilometre link between the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.
1924 : A Sydney report said that architects of modern
buildings were doing away with post verandahs.
1932 : In Britain, 19 miners drowned when a pit cage
crashed into water at the bottom of Plank Lane Colliery in Lancashire.
1940 : A German bomb destroyed the high altar of St
Paul's Cathedral in London. No text received
1956 : Mobs attacked Europeans as anti-British riots
swept through Hong Kong.
1957 : Brisbane sweltered as the temperature reached
110.2 degrees Farenheit, the hottest day for 64 years.
1962 : The United States "Mariner II" space probe
revealed the existence of solar winds.
1972 : Two men appeared in a Melbourne court charged with

kidnapping six small girls and their school teacher, five days earlier. The children and their 19 year old teacher MARY GIBBS were driven through bushland and held overnight in the back of a baker's van. The kidnappers demanded one million dollars in ransom from the Victorian government. When the men left the van to meet a government minister to collect the ransom, the teacher kicked her way out of the van and led the girls through the bush. Rabbit hunters then took them to the local police station. The kidnappers never collected the money and fled when they found the van empty.
1975 : After an already confusing past, Hollywood stars
RICHARD BURTON and ELIZABETH TAYLOR remarried in a remote Botswana village. They had married and divorced each other once prior to this marriage. They subsequently divorced again.
1985 : Hollywood actor YUL BRYNER died from cancer. The
bald-headed American actor was best known for his role in "The King And I". No text received
1985 : ORSON WELLES, U.S. stage, radio, film and
television actor, director and producer, died. His film "Citizen Kane" is regarded as one of the great classics of the cinema.
1994 : Former Melbourne football identity HARRY BEITZEL
was jailed for 18 months after pleading guilty to mis-using 1.8 million dollars, taken from soccer pools winners.
1995 : Israel began its West Bank pullback and freed
hundreds of Palestinian prisoners under a deal with the Palestine Liberation Organisation; some inmates refused to go in solidarity with others left behind.
